cards.name: AWOL
cards.text: Exile target attacking creature. Then remove it from the game. Then put it into the absolutely-removed-from-the-freaking-game-forever zone.

cards.name: AWOL
cards.text: Exile target attacking creature. Then remove it from the game. Then put it into the absolutely-removed-from-the-freaking-game-forever zone.

cards.name: Bosom Buddy
cards.text: Whenever you cast a spell, you may gain ½ life for each word in that spell's name.
cards.flavorText: "Step 1: I believe in a power and toughness greater than myself . . . ."

Flying

Flying

cards.name: Cheap Ass
cards.text: Spells you cast cost {½} less to cast.
cards.flavorText: And you thought Yawgmoth drove a hard bargain.

cards.artist: Jim “Stop the Da Vinci Beatdown” Pavelec
cards.name: Circle of Protection: Art
cards.text:
As Circle of Protection: Art enters the battlefield, choose an artist.
{1}{W}: The next time a source of your choice with art by the chosen artist would deal damage to you this turn, prevent that damage.
{1}{W}: Return Circle of Protection: Art to its owner's hand.

cards.name: Collector Protector
cards.text: {W}, Give an opponent a nonland card you own from outside the game: Prevent the next 1 damage that would be dealt to you or Collector Protector this turn.
cards.flavorText: "Here—have a Mudhole."

cards.name: Drawn Together
cards.text:
As Drawn Together enters the battlefield, choose an artist.
Creatures with art by the chosen artist get +2/+2.
cards.flavorText:
"My Pete Venters theme deck is nearly complete. Then I shall be unstoppable! Bwahahahaaa!"
—Pete Venters

cards.name: Emcee
cards.text: Whenever another creature enters the battlefield, you may stand up and say in a deep, booming voice, "Presenting . . . " and that creature's name. If you do, put a +1/+1 counter on that creature.
cards.flavorText: The ogre appealed the match loss and got it downgraded to a warning.

rulings.text: If you control more than one Emcee, each ability triggers separately. You have to announce the creature’s entrance each time. Okay, you can just stay standing if you want.
Emcee’s ability will trigger whenever a creature enters the battlefield under an opponent’s control. You choose whether you announce its arrival or not.

You may add in nicknames for the creatures you announce, but you must also get the creature’s actual name in there to count. For example, “Gary, the Gray Merchant of Asphodel” is fine, but simply “Gary” wouldn’t work.
If you are unable (not just unwilling) to use a deep, booming voice, you are free to make accommodations in the spirit of Emcee. Sign overly dramatically, for example.

cards.name: Emcee
cards.text: Whenever another creature enters the battlefield, you may stand up and say in a deep, booming voice, "Presenting . . . " and that creature's name. If you do, put a +1/+1 counter on that creature.
cards.flavorText: The ogre appealed the match loss and got it downgraded to a warning.

rulings.text: If you control more than one Emcee, each ability triggers separately. You have to announce the creature’s entrance each time. Okay, you can just stay standing if you want.
Emcee’s ability will trigger whenever a creature enters the battlefield under an opponent’s control. You choose whether you announce its arrival or not.

You may add in nicknames for the creatures you announce, but you must also get the creature’s actual name in there to count. For example, “Gary, the Gray Merchant of Asphodel” is fine, but simply “Gary” wouldn’t work.
If you are unable (not just unwilling) to use a deep, booming voice, you are free to make accommodations in the spirit of Emcee. Sign overly dramatically, for example.

cards.artist: Pete “Yes the Urza's Legacy One” Venters
cards.name: Erase (Not the Urza's Legacy One)
cards.text:
If you control two or more white permanents that share an artist, you may cast this spell without paying its mana cost.
Exile target enchantment.
cards.flavorText: Synonyms for "erase" we haven't used: ablate, a̶b̶r̶a̶d̶e̶, chafe, fray, f̶r̶a̶z̶z̶l̶e̶, scuff, and scrub.

rulings.text: This card recieved errata for its flavor text on Gatherer: http://gatherer.wizards.com/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?multiverseid=74275

cards.name: Fascist Art Director
cards.text: {W}{W}: Fascist Art Director gains protection from the artist of your choice until end of turn.
cards.flavorText: Dear Mr. and Mrs. Cranford, After careful analysis of Jeremy's vocational testing, I feel that he is best suited for a career in either torture or art direction.

cards.name: First Come, First Served
cards.text: Each attacking or blocking creature with the lowest collector number among attacking or blocking creatures has first strike.
cards.flavorText: Yotian soldiers hoped that one day R&D would make an artifact creature whose name starts with Z. And in their dreams, it's a 4/1.

cards.name: Frankie Peanuts
cards.text: At the beginning of your upkeep, you may ask target player a yes-or-no question. If you do, that player answers the question truthfully and abides by that answer if able until end of turn.
cards.flavorText: Don't cross him or you'll end up sleeping with the merfolk.

rulings.text: If you’re the player answering the yes-or-no question, you must abide by your answer if able. For example, if you are asked “Is the Slaying Mantis you control going to attack on your next turn?” and you say yes, then it must attack if able. However, if it’s tapped as you declare attackers that turn, then you aren’t able to attack with it, and you don’t have to abide by your answer.
Frankie Peanuts hates snitches, but he detests unsporting conduct. Keep your questions appropriate for your game and its surroundings.

cards.name: Head to Head
cards.text: You and target opponent play Seven Questions with the top card of that player's library. If you win, prevent all damage that would be dealt this turn by a source of your choice. (To play Seven Questions, that player looks at the card, then you ask up to six yes-or-no questions about the card that they answer truthfully. You guess the card's name—that's question seven—then the player reveals the card.)

cards.name: Ladies' Knight
cards.text:
Flying
Spells cast by players wearing at least one item of women's clothing cost {1} less to cast. (You can define women's clothing as you see fit. Be reasonable.)
cards.flavorText:
"I said 'Put him in a *core set*, not a corset!'"
—Richard Garfield, Ph.D.

cards.name: Little Girl
cards.flavorText: In the future, she may be a distinguished leader, a great scholar, or a decorated hero. These days all she does is pee the bed.

cards.name: Look at Me, I'm R&D
cards.text:
As Look at Me, I'm R&D comes into play, choose a number and a second number one higher or one lower than that number.
All instances of the first chosen number on permanents, spells, and cards in any zone are the second chosen number.

rulings.text: Look at Me, I’m R&D applies to all numbers that appear on the card, including numbers in mana symbols, rules text, power, toughness, collector number, and art.
You can choose a number with a fraction.
Note that you are changing numbers, not numerals within a number. Choosing 2 and 3 won’t change 20 to 30 or ½ to ⅓.
If you choose 0 for the first number, you are allowed to choose -1 for the second. The same is true for ½ and -½.

cards.name: Man of Measure
cards.text:
As long as you're shorter than an opponent, Man of Measure gets +0/+1 and has first strike.
As long as you're taller than an opponent, Man of Measure gets +1/+0.
cards.flavorText: You need to be this tall to play this card.

cards.name: Save Life
cards.text:
Choose one —
• Target player gains 2½ life.
• Prevent the next 2½ damage that would be dealt to target creature this turn.
Gotcha — If an opponent says "save" or "life," you may say "Gotcha!" When you do, return Save Life from your graveyard to your hand.
cards.flavorText: Who consistently managed to win.

cards.name: Standing Army
cards.text: As long as you're standing, Standing Army has vigilance.
cards.flavorText: They're the chair-men of the bored.

cards.name: Standing Army
cards.text: As long as you're standing, Standing Army has vigilance.
cards.flavorText: They're the chair-men of the bored.

cards.name: Staying Power
cards.text: "Until end of turn" and "this turn" effects don't end.
cards.flavorText: Mongo's fleas no longer bothered him. But the family of goblins that had moved in behind his left ear was starting to get really irritating.

cards.name: Wordmail
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets +1/+1 for each word in its name.
cards.flavorText:
"Suck on it, Stangg!"
—Sol'kanar the Swamp King

cards.text: {1}: This card's name becomes the card name of your choice. Activate anywhere, anytime.
cards.flavorText: {1}: This card's flavor text becomes the flavor text of your choice. (This ability doesn't work because it's flavor text, not rules text (but neither does this reminder text, so you figure it out).)

cards.name: Ambiguity
cards.text: Whenever a player plays a spell that counters a spell that has been played or a player plays a spell that comes into play with counters, that player may counter the next spell played or put an additional counter on a permanent that has already been played, but not countered.

cards.name: Artful Looter
cards.text:
{T}: Draw a card, then discard a card.
Whenever a permanent that shares an artist with another permanent you control enters the battlefield, untap Artful Looter.
cards.flavorText: PRICELESS PIC PILFERED Painting Found Abandoned in Graveyard Merfolk Decry Wizards' Treatment

cards.name: Avatar of Me
cards.text:
This spell costs {1} more to cast for each ten years you've been alive.
Avatar of Me's power is equal to your height in feet and its toughness is equal to your American shoe size. Round to the nearest ½.
Avatar of Me is the color of your eyes.

rulings.text: Avatar of Me is only the color of your eyes, not the color of your eyes and blue. That is, the color it gets from its last ability overrides the blue it gets from its mana cost.
Silver-bordered rules include any conceivable eye color, not just the five traditional Magic colors. If your eye are hazel, Avatar of Me is hazel.

Thanks to Avatar of Me, if you’re asked to choose a color in a silver-bordered game, you can name any color. “That dreamy shade of blue found only in the sky on a perfect afternoon… and in your eyes” is acceptable, but a little weird.
If you’re wearing colored contact lenses, Avatar of Me is whatever color your eyes appear to be. You can add or remove contact lenses to change your eye color in response to spells and abilities.
If each of your eyes is a different color (naturally or via a single contact lens), Avatar of Me is both colors.

cards.artist: Ron “Don't You Dare Change Me” Spears
cards.name: Brushstroke Paintermage
cards.text: {T}: Target permanent's artist becomes the artist of your choice until end of turn.
cards.flavorText: He gives credit where credit isn't due.

cards.name: Bursting Beebles
cards.text: Bursting Beebles can't be blocked as long as defending player controls two or more nonland permanents that share an artist.
cards.flavorText: Like thousands of others, the beebles quit Magic for several years following the release of the *Mercadian Masques* set.

cards.name: Carnivorous Death-Parrot
cards.text:
Flying
At the beginning of your upkeep, sacrifice Carnivorous Death-Parrot unless you say its flavor text.
cards.flavorText: Save a kill spell to deal with this guy.

rulings.text: You must say the flavor text out loud or use a comparable method of communicating. For example, sign language is allowed, but if you sign the flavor text, you are considered to have spoken. Goblin Mime will notice.

cards.name: Cheatyface
cards.text:
If Cheatyface is in your hand, you may sneak Cheatyface onto the battlefield. If an opponent catches you right away, that player may exile Cheatyface.
Flying

rulings.text: Cheatyface’s mana cost is {U}{U}{U}.
You must legally get Cheatyface into your hand before you can attempt to sneak it onto the battlefield. For example, you can’t sneak it in from your sideboard or collection during a game.

cards.name: Double Header
cards.text:
Flying
When Double Header enters the battlefield, you may return target permanent with a two-word name to its owner's hand.
cards.flavorText: Players that don't read flavor text aren't too bright, sorta smell, and dress funny. But let's just keep this between us, okay? They can get kind of violent.

cards.name: Flaccify
cards.text: Counter target spell unless its controller pays {3}{½}.
cards.flavorText: "Don't worry about it. It happens to every mage sooner or later."

cards.artist: Alan “Don't Feel Like You Have to Pick Me” Pollack
cards.name: Framed!
cards.text: Choose an artist. Tap all untapped permanents with art by that artist or untap all tapped permanents with art by that artist.
cards.flavorText: Who knew an 8˝ by 10˝ could feel like a 2˝ by 4˝?

cards.name: Greater Morphling
cards.text:
{2}: Greater Morphling gains your choice of banding, bushido 1, double strike, fear, flying, first strike, haste, landwalk of your choice, protection from a color of your choice, provoke, rampage 1, shadow, or trample until end of turn.
{2}: Greater Morphling becomes the colors of your choice until end of turn.
{2}: Greater Morphling becomes the creature type of your choice until end of turn.
{2}: Greater Morphling's expansion symbol becomes the symbol of your choice until end of turn.
{2}: Greater Morphling's art becomes by the artist of your choice until end of turn.
{2}: Greater Morphling gets +2/-2 or -2/+2 until end of turn.
{2}: Untap Greater Morphling.

cards.name: Greater Morphling
cards.text:
{2}: Greater Morphling gains your choice of banding, bushido 1, double strike, fear, flying, first strike, haste, landwalk of your choice, protection from a color of your choice, provoke, rampage 1, shadow, or trample until end of turn.
{2}: Greater Morphling becomes the colors of your choice until end of turn.
{2}: Greater Morphling becomes the creature type of your choice until end of turn.
{2}: Greater Morphling's expansion symbol becomes the symbol of your choice until end of turn.
{2}: Greater Morphling's art becomes by the artist of your choice until end of turn.
{2}: Greater Morphling gets +2/-2 or -2/+2 until end of turn.
{2}: Untap Greater Morphling.

cards.name: Johnny, Combo Player
cards.text: {4}: Search your library for a card, put that card into your hand, then shuffle.
cards.flavorText: "Just wait till I get my Krark-Clan Ironworks, Genesis Chamber, and Grinding Station. Oh yeah, and a second Myr Retriever."

cards.name: Loose Lips
cards.text:
Enchant creature
As Loose Lips enters the battlefield, choose a sentence with eight or fewer words.
Enchanted creature has flying.
Whenever enchanted creature deals damage to an opponent, that player may say the chosen sentence. If they don't, you draw two cards.
cards.flavorText: Your sentence can't be longer than this one.

cards.name: Magical Hacker
cards.text: {U}: Change the text of target spell or permanent by replacing all instances of + with -, and vice versa, until end of turn.

cards.name: Mise
cards.text: Choose a nonland card name, then reveal the top card of your library. If that card has the chosen name, you draw three cards.
cards.flavorText: mise 'miz v alter. of might as well (1997) 1: to win when you don't deserve to 2: to top-deck the "tings" you need 3: to be rewarded by an opponent's bad luck 4: to coin a phrase that spreads through the tournament scene like wildfire 5: to fling a monkey 6: to split firewood using a sharp instrument 7: To burn

cards.name: Moniker Mage
cards.text:
{U}, Say your middle name: Moniker Mage gains shroud until end of turn.
{U}, Say an opponent's middle name: Moniker Mage gains flying until end of turn.

cards.name: Mouth to Mouth
cards.text: Choose target opponent and target creature they control. You and that player have a breath-holding contest. If you win, you gain control of that creature.
cards.flavorText: Interesting tidbit: Surveys show that the card Ow has one of the most popular pieces of flavor text in the *Unglued* expansion.

cards.name: Now I Know My ABC's
cards.text: At the beginning of your upkeep, if you control permanents with names that include all twenty-six letters of the English alphabet, you win the game.
cards.flavorText: The quick onyx goblin jumps over the lazy dwarf.

cards.name: Number Crunch
cards.text:
Return target permanent to its owner's hand.
Gotcha — If an opponent says a number, you may say "Gotcha!" When you do, return Number Crunch from your graveyard to your hand.
cards.flavorText: Can you digit?

cards.name: Question Elemental?
cards.text:
Did you know this creature has flying?
Are you aware that any time you say something that isn't a question, when a player points out this fact first, they gain control of Question Elemental?
cards.flavorText: "What the . . . ?"

cards.name: Question Elemental?
cards.text:
Did you know this creature has flying?
Are you aware that any time you say something that isn't a question, when a player points out this fact first, they gain control of Question Elemental?
cards.flavorText: "What the . . . ?"

cards.name: Richard Garfield, Ph.D.
cards.text: You may play cards as though they were other cards of your choice with the same mana cost. You can't choose the same card twice. (Mana cost includes color.)
cards.flavorText: And yea he doth spake: "Let there be Magic."

rulings.text: Richard Garfield, Ph.D. essentially makes you play a variant of the Magic game called “Mental Magic.” Here’s how the game works. Whenever you cast a spell, you reveal the card to all players and choose any other card (see below for the cards that you can use) that has that card’s mana cost. (Note that color very much does matter.) That spell can then be cast as though it was the chosen card. You aren’t allowed to choose the same card twice.

By default, you are limited to cards legal in the format you’re playing. If you’re playing Draft or Sealed Deck, you can name any card available in the format you’re playing. If you’re playing with Unsanctioned decks, anything goes. Discuss with your playgroup if you’d prefer to modify or eliminate these limitations.
Playing cards as though they were other cards is optional.
Each Richard tracks its own list of played cards. If one leaves the battlefield and another enters, cards previously played under the first Richard are available once again.

If more than one player controls a Richard Garfield, Ph.D., the cards one player plays has no effect on the other players. For example, each player could play Savannah Lions as a Swords to Plowshares this way.

The same is true if Richard Garfield, Ph.D. changes controllers. If you play a Savannah Lions as Swords to Plowshares, then an opponent gains control of Richard Garfield, Ph.D., that player can then do the same.

cards.name: Richard Garfield, Ph.D.
cards.text: You may play cards as though they were other cards of your choice with the same mana cost. You can't choose the same card twice. (Mana cost includes color.)
cards.flavorText: And yea he doth spake: "Let there be Magic."

rulings.text: Richard Garfield, Ph.D. essentially makes you play a variant of the Magic game called “Mental Magic.” Here’s how the game works. Whenever you cast a spell, you reveal the card to all players and choose any other card (see below for the cards that you can use) that has that card’s mana cost. (Note that color very much does matter.) That spell can then be cast as though it was the chosen card. You aren’t allowed to choose the same card twice.

By default, you are limited to cards legal in the format you’re playing. If you’re playing Draft or Sealed Deck, you can name any card available in the format you’re playing. If you’re playing with Unsanctioned decks, anything goes. Discuss with your playgroup if you’d prefer to modify or eliminate these limitations.
Playing cards as though they were other cards is optional.
Each Richard tracks its own list of played cards. If one leaves the battlefield and another enters, cards previously played under the first Richard are available once again.

If more than one player controls a Richard Garfield, Ph.D., the cards one player plays has no effect on the other players. For example, each player could play Savannah Lions as a Swords to Plowshares this way.

The same is true if Richard Garfield, Ph.D. changes controllers. If you play a Savannah Lions as Swords to Plowshares, then an opponent gains control of Richard Garfield, Ph.D., that player can then do the same.

cards.name: Smart Ass
cards.text: Whenever Smart Ass attacks, choose a card name. If defending player has no cards with the chosen name in their hand, they may reveal their hand. If they don't reveal their hand, Smart Ass can't be blocked this turn.
cards.flavorText: "I don't get it. Why doesn't anybody like me?"

cards.name: Spell Counter
cards.text:
Counter target spell.
Gotcha — If an opponent says "spell" or "counter," you may say "Gotcha!" When you do, return Spell Counter from your graveyard to your hand.
cards.flavorText: Playing *Unhinged*, . . .

cards.name: Topsy Turvy
cards.text:
The phases of each player's turn are reversed. (The phases are, in reverse order, ending, postcombat main, combat, precombat main, and beginning.)
As long as there are more than two players in the game, the turn order is reversed.
cards.flavorText: "Here on going is heck the what?"

rulings.text: Steps within each phase play out as normal. For example, although the beginning phase happens last in a turn, the untap, upkeep, and draw steps happen in their traditional order. (If it were the other way, combat would require psychics to get through.)
Any even number of Topsy Turvys (Turvies?) will essentially cancel each other out and return the order of phases to their normal order.

cards.name: Aesthetic Consultation
cards.text: Choose an artist. Exile the top six cards of your library, then reveal cards from the top of your library until you reveal a card with art by the chosen artist. Put that card in your hand and exile all other cards revealed this way.

cards.name: Aesthetic Consultation
cards.text: Choose an artist. Exile the top six cards of your library, then reveal cards from the top of your library until you reveal a card with art by the chosen artist. Put that card in your hand and exile all other cards revealed this way.

cards.name: Bad Ass
cards.text: {1}{B}, Growl: Regenerate Bad Ass.
cards.flavorText: He wanders the land in search of Good Ass.

cards.name: Bad Ass
cards.text: {1}{B}, Growl: Regenerate Bad Ass.
cards.flavorText: He wanders the land in search of Good Ass.

cards.name: Bloodletter
cards.text: When the names of three or more nonland permanents begin with the same letter, sacrifice Bloodletter. If you do, it deals 2 damage to each creature and each player.
cards.flavorText:
"That's not really an A. It's an Æ. They changed it! Wait, don't—"
—Hœbrus Væm, Aerathi librarian, last words

rulings.text: This card recieved errata for its flavor text on Gatherer: http://gatherer.wizards.com/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?multiverseid=73979

cards.name: Booster Tutor
cards.text: Open a sealed Magic booster pack, reveal the cards, and put one of them into your hand. (Remove that card from your deck before beginning a new game.)
cards.flavorText: Real men use *Arabian Nights* boosters.

rulings.text: You can use any sealed Magic booster pack, including promo packs. As long as it hasn’t previously been opened and you don’t know the contents beforehand, you’re good.
You can open booster packs that contain cards not legal in the format you’re playing.

cards.name: Duh
cards.text: Destroy target creature with reminder text. (Reminder text is any italicized text in parentheses that explains rules you already know.)
cards.flavorText: Will players understand that the creature is being crushed by two parentheses? Not a chance.

rulings.text: Look at the actual creature you’re hoping to destroy to see if it has reminder text. Its Oracle text doesn’t matter for this purpose. It also doesn’t matter if another printing of the creature has (or doesn’t have) reminder text.
Duh can target a creature token only if the object you’re using to represent the token has reminder text, even if it’s a copy of a creature with reminder text.

cards.name: Enter the Dungeon
cards.text: Players play a Magic subgame under the table, starting at 5 life and using their libraries as their decks. The winner searches their library for two cards, puts those cards into their hand, then shuffles.

rulings.text: If Enter the Dungeon is cast during a subgame, a sub-subgame begins, preferably under a new, smaller table, but do what you can. The winner of the sub-sub game would search their subgame library for two cards.

cards.name: Eye to Eye
cards.text: You and target creature's controller have a staring contest. If you win, destroy that creature.
cards.flavorText: True, Gargox had blinded himself for life, but the glass eyes never lost.

cards.name: The Fallen Apart
cards.text:
The Fallen Apart enters the battlefield with two arms and two legs.
Whenever damage is dealt to The Fallen Apart, remove an arm or a leg from it.
The Fallen Apart can't attack if it has no legs and can't block if it has no arms.

cards.name: Farewell to Arms
cards.text:
As Farewell to Arms enters the battlefield, choose a hand attached to an opponent's arm.
When the chosen hand isn't behind its owner's back, sacrifice Farewell to Arms. If you do, that player discards their hand . . . of cards. (The lawyers wouldn't let us do it the other way.)

cards.name: Farewell to Arms
cards.text:
As Farewell to Arms enters the battlefield, choose a hand attached to an opponent's arm.
When the chosen hand isn't behind its owner's back, sacrifice Farewell to Arms. If you do, that player discards their hand . . . of cards. (The lawyers wouldn't let us do it the other way.)

cards.name: Infernal Spawn of Infernal Spawn of Evil
cards.text:
Flying, first strike, trample
Once each turn, while you're searching your library, you may pay {1}{B}, reveal Infernal Spawn of Infernal Spawn of Evil from your library and say "I'm coming, too!" If you do, Infernal Spawn of Infernal Spawn of Evil deals 2 damage to a player of your choice.

rulings.text: Infernal Spawn of Infernal Spawn of Evil doesn’t itself allow you to search your library. You must have another spell or ability that instructs you to search it.
You can reveal Infernal Spawn of Infernal Spawn of Evil any time while searching your library before you shuffle it.
If you have multiple copies in your library while searching it, you may reveal all of them, provided you can pay the {1}{B} for each of them.

If you search your library multiple times in the same turn, each Infernal Spawn of Infernal Spawn of Evil in that library can be revealed once that turn. You may reveal multiples to prove you have multiples.

cards.name: Kill! Destroy!
cards.text:
Destroy target nonblack creature.
Gotcha — If an opponent says "kill" or "destroy," you may say "Gotcha!" When you do, return Kill! Destroy! from your graveyard to your hand.
cards.flavorText: Getting "Gotcha'ed" again and again.

cards.name: Mother of Goons
cards.text: Whenever a creature an opponent controls dies, sacrifice Mother of Goons unless you insult that creature.
cards.flavorText: "Word to me."

cards.name: Necro-Impotence
cards.text:
Skip your untap step.
At the beginning of your upkeep, you may pay X life. If you do, untap X permanents.
Pay ½ life: Exile the top card of your library face down. Put that card into your hand at the beginning of the next end step.

cards.name: Persecute Artist
cards.text: Choose an artist other than Rebecca Guay. Target player reveals their hand and discards all nonland cards with art by the chosen artist.
cards.flavorText: The torches and pitchforks were no match for Rebecca's fans.

cards.name: Phyrexian Librarian
cards.text:
Flying, trample
At the beginning of your upkeep, exile the top card of your library and balance it on your body.
When a balanced card falls or touches another balanced card, sacrifice Phyrexian Librarian.

cards.name: Stop That
cards.text:
Target player discards a card.
Gotcha — If an opponent audibly flicks the cards in their hand, you may say "Gotcha!" When you do, return Stop That from your graveyard to your hand.
cards.flavorText: Now for a squirt of lemon juice.

cards.name: Tainted Monkey
cards.text: {T}: Choose a word. Target player mills a card. If a card with the chosen word in its text box was milled this way, they lose 3 life.
cards.flavorText: "C'mon, choose 'monkey.' Everybody loves monkeys!"

cards.name: Vile Bile
cards.text: Whenever a player's skin or fingernail touches Vile Bile, that player loses 2 life.

cards.name: Blast from the Past
cards.text:
Madness {R}, cycling {1}{R}, kicker {2}{R}, flashback {3}{R}, buyback {4}{R}
Blast from the Past deals 2 damage to any target. If this spell was kicked, create a 1/1 red Goblin creature token.

rulings.text: If you cycle Blast from the Past, you can then use madness to cast it. If you cast Blast from the Past using madness, you may also pay for kicker or buyback.
Flashback and buyback don’t mix. If you cast Blast from the Past using flashback, it will be exiled rather than go back to your hand.
Flashback and kicker do mix. You can pay the kicker cost in addition to the flashback cost to get the extra Goblin token.

cards.name: Touch and Go
cards.text:

Gotcha — If an opponent touches their face, you may say "Gotcha!" When you do, return Touch and Go from your graveyard to your hand.
cards.flavorText: Judge's ruling: The interior of the face still counts as the face, so a nose-pick is legitimate grounds for saying "Gotcha"

cards.name: Yet Another Aether Vortex
cards.text:
All creatures have haste.
Players play with the top card of their libraries revealed.
Noninstant, nonsorcery cards on top of a library are on the battlefield under their owner's control in addition to being in that library.
cards.flavorText: It puts the "vortex" in "flavortext."

rulings.text: If the top card of your library is a creature, planeswalker, land, enchantment, or artifact card, it’s also on the battlefield. Ta-da! This is, as they say, very weird.
If the top card of your library is a creature card, it can attack. It does have haste, after all. It can also block.

If the top card of your library is a permanent card with an activated ability that requires it to be tapped, that ability can be activated. Land cards on top of your library can be tapped for mana, and so on.

A permanent card that becomes the top card of your library enters the battlefield (unless it went from the battlefield to the top of your library), so any enters-the-battlefield abilities will trigger and “as [this creature] enters the battlefield” abilities will apply. Similarly, a permanent card that stops being the top card of your library leaves the battlefield (unless it went from the top of your library to the battlefield directly).
If the top card of your library is a creature card and it’s put into your graveyard, the creature did die. Note that it wasn’t destroyed or sacrificed or anything. It just died. <sad trombone noises>

If a creature you control that isn’t part of your library is put on top of your library, surprisingly little happens, at least at first. That creature doesn’t leave or enter the battlefield. It just stays on the battlefield. Of course, now that it’s also the top card of your library, you’ll probably draw it soon. This is also true if something puts the top card of your library directly onto the battlefield, without you having to play it.
If the top card is your library is an Aura card, that Aura is on the battlefield not attached to anything. As such, it’s put into your graveyard. The new top card of your library is then revealed.

If you are instructed to draw multiple cards, you draw them one at a time. Each card you draw after the first becomes the top card of your library briefly and is revealed. Each permanent card revealed this way enters and then leaves the battlefield, for any abilities that care about that.

cards.name: B-I-N-G-O
cards.text:
Trample
Whenever a player casts a spell, put a chip counter on its mana value.
B-I-N-G-O gets +9/+9 for each set of three numbers in a row with chip counters on them.
cards.flavorText: There was a farmer, had a hound . . .

rulings.text: All nine rows count. You can fill rows horizontally, vertically, and diagonally. A full card with give B-I-N-G-O +72/+72.
Casting multiple spells with the same mana value has no additional benefit. Once a spot has a chip counter, it’s marked, and additional chip counters won’t do anything.

The counters are considered to be on the inherent tracker in B-I-N-G-O’s art, not on the creature itself. Those counters can’t be removed or moved to another permanent. Similarly, if you proliferate, you can’t add more chip counters to B-I-N-G-O.

cards.name: Creature Guy
cards.text: Gotcha — If an opponent says "creature" or "guy," you may say "Gotcha!" When you do, return Creature Guy from your graveyard to your hand.
cards.flavorText: There once was a player named Quinn, . . .

cards.name: Elvish House Party
cards.text: Elvish House Party's power and toughness are each equal to the current hour, using the twelve-hour system.
cards.flavorText: The party was going strong for nearly an hour past midnight—then all of a sudden it just petered out.

cards.name: Fat Ass

cards.name: Name Dropping
cards.text: Gotcha — If an opponent says a word that's in the name of a card in your graveyard, you may say "Gotcha!" When you do, return that card to your hand.
cards.flavorText: Gemini (May 21—June 21) This week is a good time to branch out and meet others. But don't forget your roots. Avoid commitments and open flames.

cards.name: Old Fogey
cards.text: Phasing, cumulative upkeep {1}, echo {G}{G}, fading 3, bands with other Dinosaurs, protection from Homarids, snow-covered plainswalk, flanking, rampage 2
cards.flavorText: "These kids today with their collector numbers and their newfangled tap symbol. Twenty Black Lotuses and twenty Plague Rats. Now that's *real* Magic."

rulings.text: Due to changes in how echo and phasing work since Old Fogey was originally printed, echo mostly does nothing in this case. This is, as they say, a bit weird. Old Fogey is phased out when its echo ability would trigger, so that ability doesn’t trigger at the beginning of the upkeep after Old Fogey enters the battlefield. Phasing in doesn’t cause Old Fogey to enter the battlefield, so echo ends up not really doing much at all.

cards.name: Old Fogey

rulings.text: Due to changes in how echo and phasing work since Old Fogey was originally printed, echo mostly does nothing in this case. This is, as they say, a bit weird. Old Fogey is phased out when its echo ability would trigger, so that ability doesn’t trigger at the beginning of the upkeep after Old Fogey enters the battlefield. Phasing in doesn’t cause Old Fogey to enter the battlefield, so echo ends up not really doing much at all.

cards.name: Pointy Finger of Doom
cards.text: {3}, {T}: Spin Pointy Finger of Doom in the middle of the table so that it rotates completely at least once, then destroy the closest permanent the finger points to.
cards.flavorText:
"I would have made a 'Spin-The-Bottle' joke if I thought anyone reading this had ever played the game."
—Bucky, flavor text writer

rulings.text: Pointy Finger of Doom must rotate at least 360 degrees to count. There is no penalty for failing to spin it properly other than you must try again.
Pointy Finger of Doom won’t destroy itself, even though it is very close to itself.
Once the Finger starts spinning, no permanents can be moved until after the ability completely resolves.
If you create a token that’s a copy of Pointy Finger of Doom, spin whatever object you’re using to represent the token. Do not use living beings to represent the token.

cards.name: Rod of Spanking
cards.text: {2}, {T}: Rod of Spanking deals 1 damage to target player. Then untap Rod of Spanking unless that player says "Thank you, sir. May I have another?"
cards.flavorText: Minutes before the campus watch busted pledge week at the Alpha Beta Unlimited house . . .

cards.name: Time Machine
cards.text: {T}: Exile Time Machine and target nontoken creature you own. Return them to the battlefield at the beginning of your upkeep on your turn X in the next game you play with one of your opponents in this game, where X is the mana value of the exiled creature.

cards.name: Time Machine
cards.text: {T}: Exile Time Machine and target nontoken creature you own. Return them to the battlefield at the beginning of your upkeep on your turn X in the next game you play with one of your opponents in this game, where X is the mana value of the exiled creature.

cards.name: Togglodyte
cards.text:
Togglodyte enters the battlefield turned on.
Whenever a player casts a spell, toggle Togglodyte's ON/OFF switch.
As long as Togglodyte is turned off, it can't attack or block, and prevent all damage it would deal.

cards.name: Toy Boat
cards.text: Cumulative upkeep—Say "Toy Boat" quickly. (At the beginning of your upkeep, put an age counter on Toy Boat, then sacrifice it unless you say "Toy Boat" once for each age counter on it—without pausing between or fumbling it.)

cards.name: Urza's Hot Tub
cards.text: {2}, Discard a card: Search your library for a card that shares a complete word in its name with the discarded card, reveal it, put it into your hand, then shuffle.
cards.flavorText: www.wizards.com/hottub

cards.name: Water Gun Balloon Game
cards.text:
As Water Gun Balloon Game enters the battlefield, each player puts a pop! counter on "0."
Whenever a player casts a spell, move that player's pop! counter up one.
Whenever a player's pop! counter hits "5," that player creates a 5/5 pink Giant Teddy Bear creature token and resets all pop! counters to "0."

rulings.text: In a game with more than two players, players can use paper and pencil to track where their pop! counter is. That is, the tracker located in Water Gun Balloon Game’s art is fun, but not required to work.
Pink joins gold and every eye color imaginable in the set of colors in silver-bordered Magic games.

The pop! counters are considered to be on the inherent tracker in Water Gun Balloon Game’s art, not on the permanent itself. Those counters can’t be removed or moved to another permanent. Similarly, if you proliferate, you can’t add more pop! counters to Water Gun Balloon Game.
